name: Rio Grande (Guapay) Megafan
description: The Rio Grande (Guapay) megafan is an exceptional example of a large fluvial system in the Chaco plain. Dr. Sounny's work assesses its geomorphic and chronological aggradation patterns.

name: Kosi Megafan
description: Recognized as the largest "wet" alluvial megafan in the world. The Kosi River is a high-energy, mountain-fed system with a braided morphology and high sediment load, migrating over 110 km in 250 years.

name: Parana Megafan
description: A massive alluvial feature identified by NASA Earth Observatory. This "fossil" megafan was created by the migration of the Parana River and is recognized for its distinctive fan-shaped arrangement of ancient channels.

name: Southern Iran Fan
description: A dry river channel in the Zagros Mountains forms a silvery alluvial fan. The proximity of the water table allows for a belt of lush agricultural land to thrive along the fan's curve.

name: Kazakhstan Fan
description: Located in the Alakol basin, this fan is created as a mountain stream emerges from narrow peaks. The intricate network of interlacing channels creates fertile landforms in the basin.

name: Western China Fan
description: Situated at the edge of the Taklimakan Desert, this fan features active channels appearing in vivid electric blue. The braided streams eventually vanish into the desert sands.

name: Tsaidam Basin Fan
description: Formed by the Xi Taijnar He river descending from the Tibetan Plateau. The massive sediment build-up forces the river to bifurcate into multiple segments feeding two significant lakes.

name: Maniqui River Megafan
description: This fluvial megafan features one of the highest avulsion rates observed, with repeated channel shifts creating a dense network of abandoned channels covering 95%+ of its surface.

name: Okavango Delta
description: A massive endorheic alluvial fan. Unlike most fans, the Okavango empties into the Kalahari Desert, creating a unique inland delta system.

name: Gandak Megafan
description: A Himalayan mountain-fed river characterized by high discharge and a braided channel pattern. Its surface is marked by numerous paleochannels that record its migration history.

name: Pilcomayo Megafan
description: The largest known megafan on Earth at 705 km long, formed by the Pilcomayo River spreading laterally after exiting the Andes. It creates a vast triangular sediment surface with radiating paleochannels.

name: Bermejo Megafan
description: Forms at the Andean foothills where the Bermejo River deposits sediments in a distributive fluvial pattern, contributing to the massive Chaco megafan cluster.

name: Salado-Juramento Megafan
description: Features a distal plain with an integrated aquifer system, exemplifying how megafans host vast groundwater resources in Quaternary fluvial deposits.

name: Cormor Megafan
description: Records glaciofluvial aggradation pulses between 45-20 ka BP, forming a large inland fan from Andean meltwater sediment at mountain fronts.

name: Ili River Megafan
description: A massive fluvial megafan in Kazakhstan, approximately 230 km in length from its apex to its toe. The system terminates into Lake Balkhash, showing a well-defined distributive pattern across the arid landscape.
